Thus have I heard:
At one time, the Buddha was together with countless hundreds of thousands of great assemblies.
The great assembly respectfully surrounded him to listen to the Buddha's teaching of the Dharma. What he expounded was the MahÄyÄna Dharma of non-discrimination.
At that time, the World-Honored One universally observed the assembly of bodhisattvas.

At that time, there was a bodhisattva in the assembly named Non-discriminating Light. He rose from his seat, bared his right shoulder, touched his right knee to the ground, joined his palms towards the Buddha, and said to the Buddha:
May the World-Honored One please expound the Dharma door of entering non-discrimination, enabling the bodhisattvas to hear this Dharma and cultivate according to its principles.
The Buddha said:
Good man!
Listen attentively, I shall proclaim the entrance into the Dharma gate of non-discrimination.
At that time, the Bodhisattva of Undifferentiated Light again addressed the Buddha, saying:
Excellent, World-Honored One!
I joyfully wish to hear it.
At that time, the Bodhisattvas listened as instructed.
The Buddha said:
Good sons!
If Bodhisattvas hear the supreme Dharma of non-discrimination, and abide in the mind of non-discrimination, then they will be free from all discriminating characteristics.

As for the term 'non-discrimination,' one should first understand that from the initial intrinsic nature there are discriminating characteristics - the discriminating characteristics refer to the two dharmas of grasping and abandoning, and this grasping and abandoning are the characteristics of intrinsic nature discrimination - due to this, contaminated phenomena arise;
because of the contaminated characteristics, there are the five aggregates of clinging.
The five aggregates of clinging refer to the aggregate of form, the aggregate of feeling, the aggregate of perception, the aggregate of mental formations, and the aggregate of consciousness.
Good sons!
How can one be free from the characteristics of conceptual discrimination of self-nature?
It means not to give rise to a different mental state, in this way one is free from the characteristics of conceptual discrimination of self-nature.
If one grasps at characteristics that are different from self-nature, then there is something to be practiced, and one will not be able to attain unobstructed interpenetration.

Therefore, one should know that giving has no form and no characteristics of conceptual discrimination, and that morality, patience, vigor, meditation, and wisdom have no form and no characteristics of conceptual discrimination.
Why is this?
It is because self-nature has no form, function has no form, and reality has no form.

If one gives rise to a different mental state with the intention of being free from the characteristics of conceptual discrimination, then there will subsequently be characteristics of conceptual discrimination that can be separated from;
in this way there will be something to be practiced, and one will not be able to attain unobstructed interpenetration.
Therefore, one should know that emptiness has no form and no characteristics of conceptual discrimination.
Suchness, the ultimate reality, the ultimate truth, and the dharma realm have no form and no characteristics of conceptual discrimination.
Why is this?

Namely, the nature of non-form, the non-form of function, and the true non-form. Therefore, one should not view the nature of non-differentiation in the characteristics of non-form as different, nor should one intentionally depart from it.
If one departs from it with a different intention, then there will be something attained after the characteristics of non-form and non-differentiation.
In this way, one will have something to practice, and will not be able to attain the unobstructed interpenetration of phenomena.
Why is it so?

It is because the Dharma attained in the first ground has the characteristics of non-form and non-differentiation;ğŸ”½The Dharma attained up to the tenth ground also has the characteristics of non-form and non-differentiation;
The attainment of the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas also has the characteristics of non-form and non-differentiation;
The attainment of the prediction of Buddhahood also has the characteristics of non-form and non-differentiation;
The attainment of the adornment and purification of the Buddha land and the maturation of sentient beings also has the characteristics of non-form and non-differentiation;
Up to the attainment of the cognition of all aspects also has the characteristics of non-form and non-differentiation.
This is what is meant by the formlessness of intrinsic nature, the formlessness of effort, and the formlessness of reality.

If a bodhisattva, having attained these dharmas, gives rise to a different attainment, discriminates different characteristics, and has a different attitude, then with regard to all the characteristics of non-discrimination, he will give rise to a different attitude. In this way, he will not be in accord with the principle of non-discrimination, and he will not be able to enter the realm of non-discrimination.

If a bodhisattva abides in samÄdhi, enters the realm of non-discrimination with the mind, and gives rise to the thought of non-attainment with regard to what is entered, then he is in proper accord, this is the proper practice, this is the proper cultivation, the proper activity, the proper attitude, abiding in the practice of non-action without giving rise to realization. This is called truly entering the realm of non-discrimination and the purity of practice.
Good man, as for the realm of non-discrimination, what is the meaning of calling it the realm of non-discrimination?

It means transcending all conceptualization of form, transcending all conceptualization of faculties, transcending all conceptualized objects, transcending all expressions, and being free from the entanglements of afflictions and secondary afflictions. Therefore, it is called the realm of non-discrimination.

In this realm of non-discrimination, there is no form, no seeing, no abiding, no obstruction, no expression, and no various characteristics. If a bodhisattva understands in this way and abides in the realm of non-discrimination in this way, then he enters the wisdom of non-discrimination, which is equal to space. He observes without observing anything in all dharmas, attains the practice of great joy, increases the great mind, attains great wisdom, and becomes a great unobstructed speaker.
At all times and in all aspects, he universally benefits all sentient beings, attains the increase of courageous strength, and attains great ease in the Buddha's work without exertion.
Good man!

It is like a great rocky mountain in one place, under which there is a great treasure trove filled with various treasures, namely silver treasures, gold treasures, and various other treasures, and also a great maá¹‡i jewel emitting a great light.
At that time, there was a person seeking treasures who came to this mountain, wishing to seek precious treasures.
There was a person who knew beforehand the place where the treasures were hidden. Seeing the seeker who had come, he said to him:

You who seek treasures, you should know that under this great rocky mountain there is a great treasure trove filled with various treasures, and also a great maá¹‡i jewel appearing with a radiant light.
When the person seeking treasures heard these words, he immediately diligently and firmly made up his mind, opened up the mountain, and took the great maá¹‡i jewel.
After opening it, he saw the silver treasures appearing with light, while the stones had no light appearing.
This person, having seen this, did not think of it as a great precious treasure.

The person who knows about treasures is also like the person mentioned before. They open up the mountain and take out the treasures. After opening it, they see that the gold treasures are shining while the stones are not shining. This person also does not think of them as great treasures.
At that time, the person who knows about treasures says this:
You who seek treasures, should not diligently and firmly make efforts to seek the great treasures.
If you do not make efforts, you should be able to see those vast and precious treasures;
Because of making efforts, you cannot obtain the treasures.

If there is someone who obtains those great and precious treasures, they will immediately become greatly wealthy, freely as they wish, benefiting both themselves and others, universally accomplishing all that they wish to do.
The Buddha said:
Good man, these matters are explained through parables. If there are bodhisattvas who understand this meaning, they will see this meaning as it was previously explained.
The one great rocky mountain is a metaphor for the one dharma of afflictions, which functions in two ways;
The treasure beneath the mountain is a synonym for the realm of non-discrimination;
The person seeking treasure is a synonym for the bodhisattva;
The person who knows the treasure is a synonym for the TathÄgata;
The nature of the stone is a synonym for the nature of discrimination;
Chiseling to obtain the treasure is a synonym for non-attention;ğŸ”½The silver light beneath the stone is a synonym for the discrimination of self-nature;
The golden light beneath the stone is a synonym for the characteristics of discrimination such as emptiness;
The various precious lights beneath the stone are a synonym for the characteristics of discrimination with attainment;
Aspiring for the great treasure is a synonym for delight in entering the realm of non-discrimination.
Good man, what does this mean?
If a bodhisattva can contemplate in accordance with the teachings and in accordance with reality, then they will enter the realm of non-discrimination.
Moreover, good man!
All bodhisattvas should abide in the realm of non-discrimination, just as they abide in the realm of space.
Why is it so?
When observing the nature of form and the nature of discrimination in this way, the characteristics do not appear.
If one practices with the thought of I have form, this is the characteristic of discriminating activity;
if one practices with the thought of others have form, this is the characteristic of discriminating activity;
if one practices with the thought that form has arising, ceasing, defilement, or purity, this is the characteristic of discriminating activity;
if one grasps existence or non-existence in the nature of form, its causes, effects, actions, or practices, one oneself practices with form;
if one practices in this way, this is the characteristic of discriminating activity;
if one sees what is indicated within form, this is the characteristic of discriminating activity.

Therefore, one should know that in all cases, whether obstructed or unobstructed, indicated or unindicated, form is ultimately unobtainable;ğŸ”½within this very form, all that is unindicated and natureless can be observed;
apart from this form, all that is unindicated and natureless can be observed.
That form is obstructive and has no observable nature, in the manifested, neither a single nature can be observed nor a different nature can be observed, and that manifestation also has no nature.
This naturelessness and non-naturelessness, if observed in this way, is equal observation.
When observed in this way, all discriminations are entirely non-discriminating, this is the realm of non-discrimination.
Bodhisattvas should observe in this way, enter in this way. Entering this realm of non-discrimination, in discrimination and non-discrimination, all are non-discriminating.
Such equal observation is truly entering the realm of non-discrimination, this is called the bodhisattva attaining abiding in the realm of non-discrimination.

The emptiness of feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness, as well as the emptiness of the perfections such as giving, morality, patience, vigor, meditation, and wisdom, the truth of suchness, the ultimate truth, the truth of the highest meaning, the dharma realm, the dharmas realized on the ten grounds, up to the supramundane practices of omniscience towards all aspects, are also like this.

If one grasps existence or non-existence in feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness, up to omniscience towards all aspects, whether in terms of intrinsic nature, cause, effect, activity, or practice, then one is obstructed with respect to omniscience towards all aspects, etc.

If one practices in this way, it is practicing the characteristics of discrimination.ğŸ”½However, omniscience towards all aspects, etc. is of the nature of non-manifestation. If there were something manifested, then practicing omniscience towards all aspects, etc. would be practicing the characteristics of discrimination.
If omniscience towards all aspects, etc. had characteristics that could be practiced within manifestation, it would be practicing the characteristics of discrimination.

If one has faith in the practice of signlessness, and also practices the cognition of all aspects, etc., this is the practice of distinguishing characteristics. Therefore, one should know that this indicated Dharma is not to be seen as a single nature, nor is it to be seen as a different nature.
This indicated Dharma has no nature, and is also not without nature.

If in this way, regarding the cognition of all aspects, etc., whether indicated or not, there is no discrimination at all, and this nondiscrimination and non-grasping of characteristics is the realm of nondiscrimination.

Bodhisattvas should contemplate in this way, enter in this way. Entering in this way is true entry into the realm of nondiscrimination. This is called the bodhisattva attaining abiding in the realm of nondiscrimination.
At that time the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
If the nondiscriminating mind abides, it arises from the true Dharma of the Buddhas.
Completely free from all discrimination, one's practice then attains nondiscrimination.
This Dharma is tranquil, immaculate, and supreme, with a vast collection of fame and merit,
The supreme bliss of the non-discriminating Dharma, having attained it, the Bodhisattva accomplishes enlightenment.
